archetype_name: Family Weekend Advanced: South African Braai & Potjie
name: Venison Potjie with Root Veg and Fire-Warmed Bread Rolls
description: Slow-braised venison potjie with tomatoes, herbs, and root vegetables, cooked over coals and served with warm bread rolls for mopping up the gravy.
prep_steps: Build a medium bed of coals on the OutdoorGrill; you want gentle, steady heat for 2–3 hours.
Preheat Oven to 160°C for later warming of bread rolls (optional if not using grill to warm).
Cut venison into large chunks (about 4–5 cm).
Peel and chop onions into wedges.
Scrub carrots and cut into thick chunks.
Peel potatoes and cut into large chunks.
cook_steps: Set a heavy potjie or cast-iron pot over steady coals and heat sunflower oil until shimmering.
Season venison with salt and black pepper, then brown in batches until well colored; set aside.
Add onions to the pot and cook until softened and lightly browned. Stir in garlic for 30 seconds.
Return venison to the pot. Add crushed tomatoes, beef stock, apple cider vinegar, bay leaves, rosemary, thyme, and chilli flakes. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Cover with lid and cook over low, steady coals for 90 minutes, maintaining a gentle bubble. Rotate the pot occasionally for even heat.
Stir in carrots and potatoes. Re-cover and cook 45–60 minutes more, until venison is tender and vegetables are cooked through.
Taste and adjust with salt and black pepper. If the sauce is thin, simmer uncovered 10–15 minutes to reduce; if too thick, add a splash of beef stock.
Warm bread rolls: either place on the grill over indirect heat for 5–8 minutes, turning, or warm in the Oven for 6–8 minutes until soft inside and lightly crisp outside.
Serve the potjie hot with bread rolls for dipping.
